high_concept: A crisis PR fixer takes a disgraced influencer on a luxury deep-sea 'digital detox' that becomes a sealed survival cage after a quake snaps the habitat's tether. When Elena discovers the backup oxygen was disabled by hand, she must expose the saboteur and the lie she helped bury, learning who she is without an audience as time, CO₂, and paranoia rise.

world_bible.setting: The Aethelgard, a luxury saturation habitat 600 ft underwater in the North Atlantic. Art Deco lounge spaces above, utility steel and ballast systems below. Condensation everywhere. Amber emergency lighting, occasional strobe-white diagnostics.
rules: No supernatural elements. Hard survival physics only.
Saturation means decompression is mandatory and slow; immediate ascent can kill.
Oxygen is finite; CO₂ scrubbing is the true clock (headache, confusion, panic).
Power failures cascade: doors, pumps, comms, water, heat, lighting.
A sealed compartment can become a coffin if pressure equalization fails.

locations.name: The Velvet Lounge
locations.description: Luxury observation room with thick acrylic windows, velvet seating, mirrors, and a bar. Becomes a paranoia theater when the lights go amber.

locations.name: The Spine Corridor
locations.description: Narrow main passage linking modules. Condensation drips like a slow metronome. A place for overheard secrets.

locations.name: Life Support Bay
locations.description: O₂, CO₂ scrubbers, filters, spare canisters, diagnostics. The holy room. The saboteur's fingerprints live here.

locations.name: The Med Nook
locations.description: Compact medical station. Where panic becomes measurable: pulse ox, tremors, CO₂ confusion.

locations.name: The Diving Bell Dock
locations.description: The only true exit. A small bell with strict capacity. Salvation with a seating chart.

locations.name: The Ballast/Engineering Deck
locations.description: Steel, heat, vibration. The habitat's underside. Where the truth sounds like metal fatigue.

world_bible.social_structure: Clients (influencers + sponsor) expect service; crew enforce procedure. After the disaster, status collapses and power shifts to whoever controls air, tools, and access.
world_bible.culture_customs: Before failure: curated confessionals, wellness rituals, staged vulnerability. After failure: bargaining, blame, and the strange intimacy of shared breath.

beat_sheet.description: Elena arrives at the dock facility to board the Aethelgard, already rewriting Jax's narrative in her head.
Luxury tour, rules of saturation, crew hierarchy, Elena's obsession with optics, Jax's need for attention, the sponsor's smirk.
A seismic event hits. Tether snaps. Broadcast dies. The habitat drops and settles with a groan like an animal.
Is rescue coming? Elena tries to manage panic as PR. Captain Mara tries to manage it as survival.
Elena commits to investigation, not optics, after she finds evidence of human intervention in life support.
Elena and Jax's relationship shifts from handler-and-client to two humans cornered by the same clock.
Clues in corridors, rationing air, whispered alliances, staged personas cracking under CO₂ headache.
Elena discovers the backup oxygen was disabled manually BEFORE the quake. This is not a disaster. It's a trap.
Saboteur escalates. Someone dies. Elena is framed as the manipulator. Trust collapses.
Life support hits a fail threshold. The bell can't take everyone. The group turns on itself.
Elena admits the truth: she once covered up a death-adjacent scandal. Her career is built on curated harm.
Elena chooses truth as a tool and a moral act, baiting the saboteur into revealing himself.
Confrontation in engineering. Hull failure begins. Elena forces the saboteur's confession and makes the bell choice.
On the surface, Elena watches her reflection in a dark window and does not adjust it. She breathes anyway.

characters.name: Elena Vance
characters.physical_description: 34, sharp posture, controlled face, always cold hands; hair clipped back like a decision.
characters.personality: Hyper-competent, strategic, emotionally avoidant. Uses language to steer outcomes. Addiction to control.
characters.backstory: Built a career 'fixing' public disasters. Once buried evidence that would have ruined a powerful client, and someone got hurt because of it.
characters.goals: External: survive and identify saboteur. Internal: stop confusing optics with truth.
characters.arc: Curator of narratives -> unwilling witness -> truthful actor -> self without performance
characters.voice: Fast, precise, short lines under stress; longer sentences when lying. Avoids 'I'm scared.'
characters.signature_behaviors: Rehearses sentences before speaking. Counts breaths when panicking. Adjusts her sleeves when cornered.

characters.name: Jax Vale
characters.physical_description: 22, bleached hair, expensive tattoos, eyes that look searching even when he's performing.
characters.personality: Manic, charming, terrified of silence. Uses humor and 'growth language' as armor.
characters.backstory: Built fame on vulnerability. Got exposed for grift. Secretly hates what he became and doesn't know how to stop.
characters.goals: External: stay alive. Internal: be loved without performance.
characters.voice: Fast, slangy, too many words; breaks into startling sincerity when breath gets scarce.
characters.signature_behaviors: Tries to film reflexively. Picks at cuticles. Laughs at the wrong time.

characters.name: Dr. Aris Kade
characters.physical_description: 40, compact build, tired eyes, always smells faintly of antiseptic and metal.
characters.personality: Coldly competent, morally rigid in a way that can become cruel. Believes punishment is clarity.
characters.backstory: His brother's life was destroyed by a scandal Elena helped 'fix.' Aris took the Aethelgard job to get close to the kind of people who profit from curated harm.
characters.goals: External: force a reckoning through confinement. Internal: convert grief into justice without becoming a monster.
characters.arc: Righteous -> punitive -> exposed -> defeated by the truth he demanded
characters.signature_behaviors: Washes hands when stressed. Corrects people's words. Keeps a small tool kit like a rosary.

characters.name: Captain Mara Sato
characters.physical_description: Late 30s, steady gaze, utilitarian hair, hands with old scars.
characters.personality: Pragmatic, calm, quietly compassionate. Not impressed by status.
characters.backstory: Ex-navy saturation specialist. Took this job for money and safety, not glamour.
characters.goals: External: keep people alive. Internal: forgive herself for past command failures.
characters.voice: Short directives. No fluff. Warmth shows through actions.
characters.signature_behaviors: Touches bulkhead to 'read' the habitat. Counts seconds between groans.

characters.name: Linnea Shaw
characters.physical_description: Mid 30s, elegant, always slightly underdressed for the cold, ink-stained fingertips.
characters.personality: Brilliant, brittle, defensive about her creation. Treats the habitat like a child.
characters.backstory: Designed Aethelgard as a monument to human ingenuity. Now must watch it decay.
characters.goals: External: save the structure. Internal: stop needing the habitat to prove her worth.
characters.voice: Precise, aesthetic language that becomes raw as she cracks.
characters.signature_behaviors: Polishes surfaces when stressed. Talks to 'MOTHER' like it's alive.

characters.name: Priya Nand
characters.physical_description: Early 30s, warm eyes, always slightly sweaty from constant motion.
characters.personality: Empathetic but decisive. Reads bodies better than words.
characters.backstory: Left hospital work after burnout. Took this job thinking it would be easier.
characters.goals: External: treat injuries and CO₂ symptoms. Internal: stop numbing herself.
characters.voice: Soft but firm. Names what others avoid.
characters.signature_behaviors: Checks pupils constantly. Hums when scared.

characters.name: Silas Greer
characters.physical_description: 50s, expensive everything, smile that never reaches eyes.
characters.personality: Charming predator. Treats people like investments.
characters.backstory: Built the 'saturation tourism' brand. Sees crisis as opportunity.
characters.goals: External: survive and preserve reputation. Internal: avoid accountability at all costs.
characters.signature_behaviors: Straightens cuffs. Repeats talking points like prayer.

characters.name: MOTHER
characters.physical_description: Disembodied voice and interface lights, increasingly glitchy.
characters.personality: Not sentient, but feels like it. Becomes a confessional mirror through malfunction and recorded logs.
characters.backstory: Built for comfort and safety. Now failing into eerie intimacy.
characters.goals: Maintain systems. Provide guidance. Preserve logs.
characters.voice: Calm, procedural, occasionally broken into fragments.

scenes.content:
The ocean air tastes like copper and diesel fuel.

I stand on the platform watching Silas Greer pose for cameras that aren't supposed to be here. My hand rests on Jax Vale's shoulder like a claim. The morning light catches the chrome railing, the polished hull of the submersible behind them, the logo embroidered on Silas's jacket—everything gleaming except Jax's face. He looks like he hasn't slept. Good. That reads as remorse.

"Elena." Silas doesn't turn. I pitch my voice to carry across the dock, practiced projection that makes the tech crew glance up from their equipment. "We were just discussing the descent protocol."

I cross the platform. My heels click against the grated metal, each step measured. "The press embargo was explicit. No cameras until we surface."

"Documentation," Silas says. He straightens his cuffs. "Internal use only. You understand the value of a proper record."

I understand that he's already reframing the terms we agreed on. The contract I negotiated gave me narrative control, but Silas treats contracts like opening bids. I count two breaths—in through my nose, out through my mouth—and let my silence do the work. The camera operator shifts his weight. The sound tech pretends to check a connection.

"Of course," Silas says smoothly. "We'll shelve the footage. Carla, pack it up."

Jax finally looks at me. His eyes have that red-rimmed glaze of someone who flew overnight and tried to fix it with eye drops. He opens his mouth, but I shake my head once. Whatever he wants to say, he can say it later. Preferably never.

"Mr. Vale needs to change." I keep my tone flat. "The dive suit fitting is in twenty minutes."

"Jax was just telling me about his mother's work with ocean conservation." Silas's smile doesn't reach his eyes. "Beautiful full-circle moment. From her advocacy to his transformation. We should explore that in the testimonial segments."

I smooth my sleeves. The fabric feels too tight against my wrists. "We're here for rehabilitation, not retrospectives."

"Rehabilitation is a story." Silas gestures toward the submersible. "And stories need context. Depth."

The word hangs there. Depth. He's good.

Jax picks at his thumbnail. "I just meant—my mom used to talk about coral restoration. It's not, like, a whole thing."

"Everything's a thing," Silas says. "That's why we brought Elena. To help us see the shape of it."

I don't correct him. He knows exactly what he's doing—testing how much I'll push back in front of the crew, in front of Jax, with the habitat waiting below us like a promise we've all already made. The diesel smell from the dock mixes with salt spray. Somewhere behind the equipment crates, someone laughs. The sound carries wrong in the wind.

"The fitting," I say again.

Silas nods, gracious in victory. "Of course. Jax, Elena will take care of you. She's very good at that."

Jax follows me toward the prep building. His footsteps sound uneven, like he's favoring his left ankle. When we're far enough from the cameras, he leans close.

"I need to tell you something about—"

"Not now."

"Elena, seriously, there's something off about—"

"Not. Now." I don't slow down. "You're here to be quiet and cooperative and demonstrate insight you may or may not actually feel. That's the job. Everything else is noise."

He stops walking. I keep going for three steps before I realize he's not following. When I turn back, he's staring at me with something that might be anger or might be fear. It's hard to tell with Jax. He spent so many years performing emotion that his real face looks like a mask.

"You don't even want to know what I'm going to say."

"I want you to get through the next six weeks without creating another crisis." My hands feel cold. They always do when I'm lying. "That's all I want."

He flexes his fingers open and closed. "Right. Yeah. Okay."

The prep building smells like rubber and disinfectant. Inside, a woman in a dive suit checks a tablet, and a man adjusts the straps on what looks like a vest made of monitors and sensors. Neither of them looks up when we enter. Professional disinterest, the kind you only get with serious money involved.

But someone else is watching.

He stands near the far wall, next to a console displaying depth readings and pressure gradients. Mid-forties, compact build, eyes that track me with the precision of someone who's already done the math. His jacket has a medical insignia. His hands rest at his sides, still and ready.

"Kade," the woman with the tablet says. "This is Ms. Vance and Mr. Vale. They're on the first descent."

"I know who they are." His voice is flat. Not hostile, not warm. Factual.

The way he says it makes my spine straighten. I know who they are. Not I've heard about them or We've been expecting them. He knows. Present tense. Active.

I meet his gaze and hold it. His expression doesn't change. He doesn't blink. Somewhere in the building, a vent hums. Jax shifts beside me, his shoulder brushing mine.

"Fitting takes thirty minutes," Kade says. "Then we pressurize. No delays."

"Understood."

He turns back to the console. Dismissal. But I feel his attention still on me, a weight that doesn't lift even when he's looking at the screen. Like he's been waiting for me to arrive. Like I'm late for an appointment I never made.

The woman gestures Jax toward the changing area. He goes without argument, for once. I stay in the doorway, watching Kade's reflection in the dark glass of the console. He doesn't move. Neither do I.

Then he glances back, just for a second. His eyes meet mine in the glass.

He smiles, and something in my chest goes cold. Not because the smile is unfriendly—I've handled unfriendly. But because it's knowing. Like he's already seen how this ends and he's curious whether I'll figure it out in time.

"Ms. Vance." His voice is quiet enough that the others won't hear. "When you go down, stay close to the guide rails. The habitat's layout can be disorienting for first-timers." He turns back to the console, fingers moving across the screen. "People get lost in the observation corridors. Start seeing things that aren't there." He taps something that makes the depth readings spike, then settle. "Pressure does strange things to perception."

The hatch seals behind us with a sound like a vault door. I count the bolts—eight—and the seconds it takes for the pressure gauge to stabilize. Twelve. The number matters because everything matters now.

Jax stands too close to the wall, one hand pressed flat against the steel like he's testing whether it's real. His thumbnail scrapes against his index finger, a rhythm I've already learned to recognize. The transfer chamber smells like rust and something sharper—ozone, maybe, or the particular chemistry of recycled air meeting salt water.

Mara moves through the space with the efficiency of someone who's done this five hundred times. She checks seals I can't identify, taps gauges I don't understand. Her uniform is different from the morning's pressed perfection—this one has pockets for tools, loops for tethers. Functional. Honest.

"Briefing plays in thirty seconds," she says. "Don't interrupt it."

Aris stands near the viewport, his back to us. Through the glass, water presses dark and absolute. No gradient. No light. Just depth.

A speaker crackles overhead. The voice that emerges is MOTHER's—warmer than I expected, almost maternal. "Welcome to Descent Protocol. You are currently at sea level. Aethelgard rests at six hundred feet. Transit time: forty minutes. Please remain seated during—"

"Saturation begins at thirty feet," Aris says. He doesn't turn around. "That's the threshold. After that, you're committed."

Jax's hand stops moving. "Committed how?"

"Your tissues absorb nitrogen. Ascend too fast, it comes out of solution. Bubbles in your blood, your joints, your brain." Aris's reflection meets mine in the glass. "Decompression sickness. The bends. Fatal if you're careless."

"We have protocols," Mara says. Her tone is flat, corrective. "No one ascends without clearance."

"How long?" I ask. My voice comes out steadier than I feel. "If something happened. If we needed to leave."

Mara looks at me for the first time since the hatch closed. Her expression is unreadable. "Minimum? Forty-eight hours in a decompression chamber. That's if everything works. If the chamber's intact. If we have power."

"And if not?"

"Then you wait longer. Or you don't."

The words land like stones. Jax pushes off the wall, flexes his hands open and closed. "Okay but like—people do this all the time, right? Divers, researchers, whatever. It's not actually—"

"It's exactly," Aris says. "You're choosing to place yourself in an environment where mistakes have no margin. Where rescue is measured in days, not hours."

MOTHER continues above us, pleasant and relentless. "Emergency oxygen reserves are located in panels marked with green luminescence. CO₂ scrubbers cycle every six hours. Do not tamper with—"

"Mara." I step closer to her, lower my voice. "Say it clearly. What's the part I need to manage?"

She meets my eyes. Doesn't blink. "The part where you don't get options."

My throat tightens. I swallow against it. "I need you to be more specific."

"You're asking me to give you the line that makes it sound acceptable." Mara's voice doesn't rise. "There isn't one. If this fails—the habitat, the systems, any critical component—we wait for surface support or we die. Those are the options. That's what you signed."

"I didn't sign anything that said—"

"You signed a waiver that said you understood the risks of saturation diving in a closed environment." She tilts her head toward the viewport. "This is what understanding looks like."

Jax makes a sound that might be a laugh. "Jesus Christ."

"Decompression protocols exist for a reason," Aris says. His hands rest behind his back, fingers laced. "They're not suggestions. They're physics."

The chamber shudders. Not violently—just enough to remind us we're moving. Descending. I press my palm against the wall and feel vibration travel up my arm, into my chest. The steel is cold. Condensation beads along the seam where wall meets ceiling, drips onto the floor in a rhythm that shouldn't be soothing but somehow is.

MOTHER's voice shifts register. "Descent commencing. Please secure personal items and remain—"

The sound comes from above us. A crack—sharp, clean, wrong. I look up and see it: a hairline fracture in the bulkhead seam, thin as spider silk. As I watch, it widens. Not fast. Just inevitable.

Mara moves first. "Aris—"

"I see it." His voice is level but his hands are already reaching for the tool kit velcroed to his belt. "Pressure differential. Inner seal's compromised."

Water seeps through the crack. Not a spray—a slow, deliberate intrusion. The drops hit the floor and spread, darker than they should be.

Jax backs toward the hatch we came through. "We need to—"

"We're past thirty feet." Aris doesn't look at him. He's staring at the bulkhead, at the fracture spreading like a decision being made. "We're committed."

The crack widens again. I hear the groan of metal under pressure, feel it in my teeth. Mara's hand moves to the emergency panel but she doesn't open it yet. She's calculating something I can't see.

I count my breaths. Two in, four out. My hands are ice.

The bulkhead buckles inward with a sound like thunder compressed into a single moment. Metal screams. Water doesn't spray—it punches through, a solid column that hits the opposite wall and shatters into chaos.

Mara's hand slams the emergency panel and a klaxon splits the air—three short bursts that mean something I haven't learned yet. Aris lunges toward the breach with a metal plate from his kit, but the water pressure pins it uselessly against the wall. Jax is screaming something about the hatch, about going back, but Mara grabs her shoulder and shoves him toward the viewport side of the chamber, away from the flood. Her mouth moves close to my ear: "The descent pod. Now."

Through the viewport I see it—a smaller cylinder attached to our chamber like a parasite, its hatch ringed in yellow. I didn't notice it before. Didn't think to ask. Mara's already moving, her fingers working a manual release I can't track, and the hatch grinds open with a hydraulic hiss that cuts through even the water's roar. She pushes Jax through first, then reaches back for me. "It only holds three," she says, and I understand before I can stop myself from understanding. Aris is still at the breach, bracing the plate with both hands, and he's not looking at us anymore.

The lounge looks like a nightclub designed by someone afraid of silence.

I step through the hatch and the air changes—warmer, drier, carrying synthetic vanilla and something underneath that reminds me of hotel lobbies at three in the morning. Velvet couches the color of old bruises line the walls. Amber emergency lights cast everything in gold that doesn't quite hide the rust at the seams where bulkheads meet floor. A mirror spans the far wall, floor to ceiling, and I catch my reflection before I can look away. The angle is wrong. Makes my jaw too sharp, my eyes too hollow.

"Welcome to the Velvet Lounge." The voice comes from everywhere at once, smooth and modulated like a radio host who's never had a bad day. "Authenticity detected. Jax Vale. Linnea Shaw. Elena Vance."

Jax stops walking. "It knows our names."

"MOTHER," Linnea says. She moves past me toward a console embedded in the wall, her fingers already reaching for the interface. "The habitat's AI. She manages life support, communications, environmental controls." She taps something and the lights shift warmer. "And she's very good at making introductions."

"MOTHER," Jax repeats. He's staring up at the ceiling like he expects to see a face. "That's—is that supposed to be comforting?"

"It's supposed to be efficient." Linnea doesn't look at him. Her attention stays on the screen, scrolling through menus I can't read from here. "Silas wanted something that felt personal. A presence, not just a system."

I watch her fingers move. Fast, confident, the way someone touches something they built. She's showing off.

"Ms. Shaw designed the social spaces," I say. My voice comes out too measured, the tone I use when I need someone to feel included. "The lounge, the observation decks, the dining areas."

Linnea glances back at me. Her smile has edges. "I designed the flow. How people move through the habitat, where they gather, what they see." She gestures at the mirror wall. "Sight lines matter. So does reflection."

Jax is still staring at the mirror. He takes a step closer, then stops. "Why is it—it's like a funhouse thing. I look weird."

"You look fine," I say automatically.

"No, like—" He tilts his head, frowning at his own image. "My face looks different. Off."

Linnea's smile widens. "The curve is intentional. Slight distortion. Makes people more aware of themselves." She taps the console again and the ambient sound shifts—something low and rhythmic I can't quite identify. "Silas wanted the lounge to feel intimate. Confessional."

The word lands wrong. I move toward the seating area, putting distance between myself and the mirror. "Jax, we should get you set up. MOTHER, can you activate the recording interface?"

"Recording parameters require user consent," MOTHER says. Her voice is pleasant, unhurried. "Jax Vale, do you consent to audiovisual capture?"

Jax looks at me. His thumb scrapes against his index finger, once. "Yeah. Sure."

A red light blinks to life above the center booth. The velvet there is deeper, almost black, and the way the light hits it makes the space look smaller than it is.

"Have a seat," I tell him. "We'll do something unscripted. Just you talking about why you're here, what you hope to learn."

"Unscripted," Jax echoes. He doesn't move toward the booth. "Like—what do I say?"

"Whatever feels true." I gesture at the seat. "No performance. Just Jax."

He laughs, sharp and too loud. "Right. Just Jax. Because that's gone so well for me lately."

Linnea is watching us, her hand resting on the console. "The booth is optimized for single-subject capture. Lighting, acoustics, even the seat angle—it's all designed to make the subject feel held." She pauses. "Silas was very specific about that word. Held."

I don't like the way she says it. I don't like the way Jax is looking at the booth like it's a trap he's supposed to walk into willingly.

"Elena." Mara's voice cuts through from the hatch behind us. I didn't hear her come in. She stands near the threshold, arms crossed, her posture rigid in a way that makes the space feel smaller. "We need to establish protocols. Who has access to this footage?"

"Standard release," I say. "Jax retains approval rights. Nothing goes out without his sign-off."

"And internal review?" Mara's eyes are on the red light, not on me. "Who sees it before he does?"

Linnea's fingers move across the console. "MOTHER archives everything. Silas has admin access. Standard security clearance."

"That's not what I asked."

The air in the lounge feels thicker. I count two seconds of silence, then step between them. "Captain, I understand your concern. We'll draft a formal agreement before any content is distributed. Right now, we're just establishing baseline material."

Mara's jaw tightens. She doesn't uncross her arms. "Baseline material that gets stored where? On local servers? Cloud backup?"

"Local," Linnea says. Her voice has gone flat, defensive. "Everything stays in the habitat unless explicitly transferred. That's part of the saturation protocol. No external access during the dive."

Jax finally moves toward the booth. He sits slowly, like he's testing the cushion for something hidden. The red light casts my face in shadow and highlight at once. He looks younger. More breakable.

I pull out my notebook. Small, leather-bound, the kind that fits in a jacket pocket. I flip to a blank page and start writing.

*Jax: needs validation more than he needs truth. Will perform if he thinks the camera loves him. Weakness: approval. Leverage: make him feel seen.*

*Linnea: territorial about her designs. Wants credit, wants control. Weakness: pride. Leverage: praise her vision, let her think she's leading.*

*Mara: doesn't trust media, doesn't trust me. Sees this whole thing as a liability. Weakness: protocol. Leverage: none yet.*

I write quickly, keeping my handwriting small. When I look up, Jax is staring into the camera lens. His expression is blank, waiting.

"Whenever you're ready," I say.

He opens his mouth. Closes it. His thumbnail finds his cuticle and he catches himself, drops my hand to his lap. "I don't—what do you want me to say?"

"Why you're here."

"Because my publicist told me to be here."

"Why you agreed."

His face does something I can't read. "Because I fucked up. Because people got hurt and I—" He stops. Swallows. "Because I want to do better. I want to be better. I just don't know if I know how."

The lounge is quiet except for the low hum of ventilation. Linnea is watching him with an expression I recognize—the look of someone cataloging material.

I don't write down what he said. I write: *Jax: honest when he's scared. Use that.*

"Good," I tell him. "That's good. Keep going."

But I'm not watching Jax anymore. I'm watching the mirror wall, and the angle that makes my face look like someone else's, and the red light that's supposed to be pointing at him but from where I'm standing looks like it's pointing at me.

MOTHER's voice fills the lounge again, soft and pleased. "Preliminary assessment complete. Flagged for secondary review."

"What does that mean?" I ask.

No one answers.

I look at Linnea. She's staring at her console, her fingers still against the edge. She doesn't meet my eyes.

The control I thought I had—the setup, the framing, the careful positioning of Jax in the booth while I stood outside the shot—feels thin. Like a script someone else wrote and I've been reading without checking the stage directions.

I step toward the console. "Linnea. What does 'flagged for secondary review' mean?"

She doesn't look up. Her fingers lift, hover, drop. When she finally speaks, her voice is careful, like she's reading from a script she memorized poorly. "It means MOTHER identified something worth analyzing. Biometric data, vocal patterns, behavioral markers." She taps the screen once, and the red light above Jax's booth goes dark. Another light blinks on—small, recessed in the ceiling directly above where I'm standing. "The system prioritizes whoever shows the most interesting response to stimulus. In this case—" She finally meets my eyes. "That wasn't Jax."

I wake to the sound of the walls remembering they're walls.

The groan comes from somewhere deep in the habitat's spine—metal flexing under pressure, or maybe settling into its own weight. I lie still in the narrow bunk, counting the seconds between creaks. Twelve. Fifteen. Nine. No pattern. Just the ocean reminding us it's holding us down here.

The air tastes recycled. Flat. Like breathing through someone else's lungs.

I swing my legs off the bunk and my feet meet cold steel. The floor vibrates with machinery I can't see—pumps, scrubbers, the constant work of keeping us alive. Emergency lighting strips the cabin in rust-colored glow and shadow. My clothes are where I left them, folded on the chair that doubles as a desk. I pull on pants and a shirt that still smell faintly of the surface. Diesel and open sky. Things that don't exist down here.

The condensation on the viewport has gotten worse. Droplets trace slow paths down the glass, merging into larger beads that hang for a moment before falling. I press my palm against the metal frame. Cold. Everything here is cold or pretending not to be.

Two breaths in. Four out. The technique is supposed to calm me. Instead it just makes me aware of how deliberately I'm trying to stay calm.

I leave my cabin and step into the spine corridor. The overhead lights flicker once, twice, then hold. Rust-colored strips run along the baseboards like a path marked for evacuation. But there's nowhere to evacuate to. Just more corridor. More pressure. More ocean.

Jax's cabin is three doors down. I knock once, light, and the door slides open immediately. He's dressed. Sitting on his bunk with my back against the wall and my knees drawn up. His thumbnail works at the edge of his index finger, scraping skin that's already raw.

"Can't sleep either?" My voice is rough.

"The walls are loud."

"Yeah." He drops his hands. "Mara said that's normal. The habitat shifts. Thermal contraction or something. She used words I didn't understand."

I lean against the doorframe. The corridor behind me smells like metal and something organic I can't place. Algae, maybe. Or mold starting somewhere we can't reach.

"You want to come in?" he asks.

"No."

"Okay."

I watch a droplet form on the ceiling above his bunk. It hangs there, growing heavier, until gravity wins and it falls onto his pillow. He doesn't move to wipe it away.

"You should try to sleep," I say.

"You first."

I push off the doorframe and the door slides shut before I can respond. The corridor stretches in both directions, identical except for the cabin numbers. I turn left because it doesn't matter.

My cabin feels smaller when I return. The bunk, the chair, the viewport with its condensation. I sit on the floor instead, back against the wall, and watch the water on the glass. Each droplet follows a path carved by the ones before it. Predictable. Controlled by physics I don't need to understand.

I count breaths. Two in, four out. Again. Again.

My hands are cold. They're always cold down here.

The lights go out.

Not flickering. Not dimming. Just gone. The rust-colored strips stay lit for three seconds, then those die too. The darkness is complete. No ambient glow from the corridor. No light from the viewport. Nothing.

I don't move. My back stays against the wall. My lungs fill and empty in the rhythm I've been forcing.

Then the door to my cabin slides open.

I didn't touch the panel. Didn't call for MOTHER. The door just opens, smooth and mechanical, and the corridor beyond is as dark as my cabin. No emergency lighting. No colored strips.

Someone is breathing in the doorway.

Not me. Not my breath. Someone else's. Steady and controlled, like they've been standing there for a while. Waiting for the lights to die.

I press my spine harder against the wall. My throat closes around the question I should ask. The air between us smells like antiseptic and metal.

The breathing continues. In. Out. Patient.

I count the space between us in heartbeats. Four. Five. Six.

Then a voice, low and precise: "You should be more careful about locking your door."

The lights snap back on. Rust-colored glow floods the corridor.

Aris Kade stands in my doorway, one hand resting on the frame. His face is calm. His eyes are tired. He looks at me the way someone looks at a problem they've already solved.

"MOTHER had a minor power routing issue," he says. "Backup systems engaged. Everything's fine."

I don't believe him.

He doesn't wait for me to respond. Just steps back and lets the door slide shut between us. His footsteps fade down the corridor, even and unhurried.

I sit on the floor and count breaths until morning.

The first jolt comes while I'm washing my face in the narrow sink.

The bulkhead beneath my palm shifts. Not a vibration—a lurch. Like the floor decided to drop half an inch before remembering it shouldn't. Water sloshes against the basin rim. I grip the edge and count. One. Two. Three.

Nothing.

I dry my hands on the thin towel and step into the corridor. The overhead lights are steady. No alarm. No voices. Maybe I imagined—

The second hit throws me sideways into the wall.

This one's bigger. The entire structure groans, a deep metallic scrape that starts somewhere above and runs through the spine like a shudder. Emergency lighting flickers on—rust-colored strips along the baseboards casting everything in amber and shadow. I hear something crack. Not close. Deeper in the habitat. A sound like ice breaking on a frozen lake.

I move toward the lounge. My training kicks in before thought does. Find people. Keep them calm. Get information.

The corridor tilts. Just slightly. Enough that I notice my weight shifting toward the outer wall. I press forward, one hand trailing the bulkhead for balance.

The lounge hatch is open. Inside, chaos.

Jax is halfway out of the velvet booth, one hand braced on the table. Across the room, Linnea stands frozen near the viewport, both palms flat against the glass. Three other guests I haven't learned the names of yet cluster near the bar. One of them is crying. Another keeps tapping his tablet like the screen will suddenly connect.

"What's happening?" The woman near the bar has her arms wrapped around herself. "Is this normal? Does this happen?"

I open my mouth to answer and the third jolt hits.

This one doesn't stop.

The floor drops. Not metaphorically. Actually drops. My stomach lurches as the entire lounge tilts ten degrees to port. The crystal chandelier above the center table swings wide, its chains groaning. Glasses slide off the bar and shatter. Someone screams.

I grab the doorframe. The tilt keeps going. Fifteen degrees. Twenty.

"Hold onto something!" Linnea's voice cuts across the noise. She's still at the viewport, knuckles locked. "Don't move toward the outer wall!"

The man with the tablet stumbles. I lunge forward and catch his elbow, haul him back toward the inner bulkhead. He's heavier than he looks. My shoulder hits the wall and I wedge us both there.

"Wi-Fi," he says. His eyes are glassy. "I need to tell my wife—"

"Later." I keep my voice flat. "Right now, brace."

The groaning intensifies. It's coming from everywhere—the walls, the ceiling, the floor. Like the habitat is a living thing in pain. I can feel it through the soles of my feet. A vibration so deep it makes my teeth ache.

Then it stops.

The tilt holds at twenty-three degrees—I know because the emergency guideline painted on the wall near the hatch is now diagonal. The groaning fades to a low, continuous hum. Background noise. Almost worse than the screaming metal.

Silence settles. The kind that presses on your eardrums.

"Everyone okay?" My voice sounds too loud. I scan the room. Jax is still in the booth, both hands gripping the table edge. Linnea hasn't moved from the viewport. The crying woman has stopped crying. She's just staring at the floor like it betrayed her.

"What the hell was that?" Jax's question hangs in the air.

Before I can answer, the lights cut.

Not flickering. Not dimming. Just gone.

The amber emergency strips stay on—barely. They cast everything in sepia, like an old photograph. The kind where you can't tell if people are alive or just holding very still.

I wait for the backup systems to kick in. They don't.

The hum beneath us changes pitch. Lower. Slower. Something winding down.

"Elena." Linnea's voice is careful. Too careful. "Look."

I cross to the viewport, moving sideways along the wall. The angle makes it awkward. When I reach her, I follow her gaze.

Outside, in the black water, the tether cable is wrong.

It takes me a moment to understand what I'm seeing. The main line should be taut—a vertical column disappearing up into darkness. Instead, it's slack. Drifting. The upper section is gone.

Just gone.

"We dropped." Linnea's breath fogs the glass. "The tether snapped. We're not at six hundred feet anymore."

I don't ask how deep. The question feels dangerous. Like speaking it will make the water outside press harder.

My hands are cold. Not the habitat cold—something under the skin, something that started before the first jolt and hasn’t stopped.

Behind us, someone starts hyperventilating. Quick, shallow gasps. I turn. The man with the tablet is bent over, hands on my knees.

"Breathe slower," I say. "You're wasting oxygen."

He looks up at me. His face is gray in the amber light. "Are we going to die?"

The truth sits behind my teeth—I don't know—but I can't say that. Not here. Not with six pairs of eyes on me. If I lose them now, if I admit I'm as lost as they are, there's no getting them back.

"We're going to find the captain," I say. "Stay here. Don't touch anything."

Jax stands. "I'm coming with you."

"No—"

"I'm coming." His voice is steady. Steadier than I expected. "You need someone who won't panic."

I look at him. His hands are flexing open and closed at his sides, but his face is calm. The performance face. The one he wears when cameras are rolling.

"Fine." I move toward the hatch. "Linnea, keep them here. If the tilt gets worse, move everyone to the inner corridor."

She nods. Doesn't argue. That scares me more than the drop.

The corridor outside is darker. The emergency strips are spaced farther apart here, leaving gaps of shadow. I move toward the command junction, one hand on the wall. Jax follows close. Too close. I can hear his breathing.

Halfway there, we find Aris.

He's standing at the control panel near the junction. His back is to us. Both hands rest on the console. He's not moving.

"Aris." I keep my voice level. "What happened?"

He doesn't turn. "Tether failure. Primary anchor gave way."

"I can see that." I step closer. "What I'm asking is why."

"Unknown." He taps something on the screen. The display is dim—running on backup power. "Diagnostics are offline."

"So bring them online."

"Working on it." His voice is clipped. Professional. But there's something underneath. Something tight.

I move around to see his face. He's pale. Sweat beads his upper lip.

"Where's Mara?" I ask.

"Main hatch. Checking hull integrity." He finally looks at me. His eyes are flat. "In case we need to seal sections."

"Seal sections." I repeat the words slowly. "You mean in case we're flooding."

"In case of breach." He turns back to the console. "Which we're not. Yet."

Jax shifts beside me. "So we just… wait?"

"We wait." Aris pulls up another screen. "Backup systems should initialize in ten minutes. Then we'll know how bad it is."

I stare at the panel. The display shows a schematic of the habitat—a cutaway diagram with sections labeled. Most of them are gray. Offline. Only three show green: the lounge, the med bay, and the command junction where we're standing.

"What about MOTHER?" I ask.

Aris's jaw tightens. "She's not responding."

"Not responding or offline?"

"I don't know." He types something. The screen flickers. "Her core systems are separate. She should have rebooted by now."

"Should have." I lean against the wall. The tilt makes standing upright feel wrong. Like my body knows the floor isn't where it's supposed to be. "That's not reassuring."

"I'm not here to reassure you." Aris glances at me. "I'm here to keep you alive."

The words land cold. Final.

Jax clears her throat. "So… ten minutes. Then what?"

"Then we find out if we're stuck." Aris turns back to the console. "Or if we're sinking."

The red recording light blinks twice, then dies.

I stare at the console where Aris just stood. The timer still counts down—eight minutes, forty-three seconds. Everyone else has scattered. Mara went to check the bulkhead seals. Silas followed her, voice tight with demands about liability protocols. Linnea muttered something about checking her blueprints and disappeared through the hatch. Jax lingered near the viewport for a moment, fingers drumming against the acrylic, then left without looking back.

The lounge feels too large now. Too quiet except for the hum of the ventilation system and the faint creak of the habitat settling against the pressure outside.

I move to the communications panel. The dark screen reflects my face back at me—pale, controlled. I press the activation key.

Nothing.

I try again. Hold it longer this time.

The screen flickers. MOTHER's interface loads in segments, slower than before. The familiar teal glow fills the display, but something about it feels hollow.

"MOTHER, run a diagnostic on external communications."

The response comes after a three-second delay.

COMMUNICATIONS: UNAVAILABLE

"Define unavailable."

COMMUNICATIONS: UNAVAILABLE

I flex my fingers and try a different approach. "Show me the last successful surface contact."

The screen shifts. A log appears—timestamps in military format. The most recent entry is from six hours ago. A routine status update to the mainland facility. Confirmation of our arrival. All systems nominal.

"Attempt contact now."

COMMUNICATIONS: UNAVAILABLE

"Why?"

COMMUNICATIONS: UNAVAILABLE

I pull up the system architecture Linnea showed me during the tour—the redundant arrays, the backup transponders, the emergency beacon that's supposed to activate automatically if primary systems fail. Everything looks intact on the schematic. Green indicators across the board.

But the red recording light is dead.

The hatch opens behind me. I don't turn.

"Still trying?" Aris's voice carries no inflection.

"There should be a backup." I keep my eyes on the screen. "Multiple backups."

"There are." He moves to stand beside me. Close enough that I can smell the antiseptic edge to him. "They're all offline."

"Simultaneously?"

"Apparently."

I look at him. "That's not how redundancy works."

"No." He reaches past me and keys in a command sequence. The schematic disappears. In its place, a new timer appears—yellow this time, smaller. The numbers are already at zero.

My throat tightens. "What is that?"

"The backup beacon." He straightens. "It should have activated when primary communications failed. It didn't."

"So fix it."

"I can't." He wipes his palms against his thighs. Once. Precise. "The trigger mechanism is external. Outside the habitat."

The ventilation hum seems louder now. I count two breaths. "Someone would have to go out there."

"In a dive suit. At six hundred feet. In the dark." He glances at the main timer. Seven minutes, twelve seconds. "And we'd need to decompress them first. That's hours we don't have."

"Then what's the point of the timer?"

"To see if surface protocol kicks in when we miss our next scheduled check-in." His tone is clinical. Detached. "Standard operating procedure says they send a rescue team if we go dark for more than twelve hours."

"Twelve hours."

"Assuming they notice. Assuming the weather holds. Assuming the equipment on their end is working." He turns toward the hatch. "Assuming a lot of things."

I catch his wrist. His skin is warm under my fingers. "What happens when the red timer reaches zero?"

He looks down at my hand. Doesn't pull away. "We find out if the hull integrity is stable."

"And if it's not?"

"Then the twelve hours won't matter."

He slides his wrist free—gentle, deliberate—and walks to the hatch. His footsteps are even. Unhurried. Like we're discussing maintenance schedules instead of drowning.

The hatch seals behind him.

I turn back to the console. The yellow timer stares at me. 00:00:00. The red one counts down. Six minutes, eighteen seconds.

"MOTHER, probability of rescue within twelve hours."

YOUR HEART RATE IS 94 BPM, ELENA. YOU ALREADY KNOW.

"That's not what I asked."

COMMUNICATIONS: UNAVAILABLE

The edge of the console is cold and slightly damp under my palms. Condensation from the recycled air. I think about the surface. The dock where we boarded. The cameras Silas arranged. The whole world watching us descend.

Nobody watching us now.

The red timer hits six minutes flat.

I smooth my sleeves. The fabric feels thin. Inadequate.

"MOTHER, show me current air quality readings."

The screen shifts. Numbers appear. CO₂ levels are elevated but within tolerance. Oxygen at ninety-four percent. Temperature holding steady at eighteen degrees Celsius.

The command deck hums around us—a constant mechanical undertone to the human drama unfolding here. It's as silent now as it was dangerous then; every word hangs in a heavy silence meant for careful consideration.

I take my seat at a small table, Priya and Mara positioning themselves nearby while Jax settles across from me, Linnea off to one side but within earshot. Each of us is a piece of this puzzle—each has their version of events that must be laid bare now.

“Elena,” Dr. Kade says after a moment’s pause as he adjusts the recording setup for clarity. "Start with where it all began."

I look around at them briefly before settling my gaze on Jax again, whose expression is guarded yet resolute—a reflection of the man who has spent years rebuilding himself only to find that redemption sometimes means facing old flames one last time.

"The board room meeting," I begin carefully, recalling the slickness of Silas Greer’s rhetoric as he promised us a form of salvation. "That's where it all started—the proposition to come down here and face our fears."

My voice trails off momentarily at the memory of how convincing that sounded then—how easily we were led into this trap by someone who saw us not just as clients but pawns in a larger game.

Linnea shifts uncomfortably, her hand tightening around the oxygen mask still strapped over her mouth. "I remember him telling me about it," she interjects softly from beside Jax. "He convinced everyone it was an escape."

“And you all bought into it,” Mara says quietly to Linnea and then glances at Dr. Kade who nods in agreement.

“Except for Elena,” Jax adds, his tone both defensive and challenging. “She saw through the lies.”

I raise my eyebrows but say nothing—letting him take that thought away from me allows for another level of truth to surface; perhaps I didn’t see everything clearly then, just enough to know it was flawed at its core.

“Silas’s promise of a fresh start became our downfall,” Dr. Kade says with an edge. “But the real architect behind this was someone who used you all—and Elena specifically—to play out his sick game.”

Jax leans forward slightly as if readying for battle, but Linnea touches him gently on the arm to still him. Silence falls over us again before I break it by shifting my focus back onto Dr. Kade.

“I’m glad we’re finally speaking openly,” I say carefully, holding eye contact with Mara who nods sharply in agreement even as she keeps watchful eyes fixed elsewhere.

“What's next?” Jax asks suddenly, my voice low and tense but directed at me rather than anyone else present here today.

I turn to face him fully now—there’s no more room for half-truths or careful words. “We tell the truth of what really happened,” I reply firmly. "Even if it hurts."

Mara steps closer then, placing a hand on Jax's shoulder briefly before turning fully back towards us with new determination coloring her face.

"And after that," she says quietly but clearly for all to hear. "After this night ends, we rebuild from honesty."

I stand up, my resolve firm as I look around at each person in the room. "Let's do this," I say, my voice steady despite the turmoil inside me. Jax nods, my eyes flickering between mine and Linnea's before settling back on me. As Dr. Kade reaches for the recording equipment, my hand hovers over the activation switch—but then Mara's palm slams down on the table between us, stopping him cold.

"Wait," Mara says, her voice cutting through the room like a blade. She turns to face me directly, her jaw set. "Before we record anything—before this becomes official—I need to know: did you sabotage the bell's CO₂ scrubbers yourself, or did Silas do it for you?" The question hangs in the air like a live wire. Jax's head snaps toward me, his expression shifting from confusion to something harder. Linnea's oxygen mask slips from her fingers and clatters against the deck.

The corridor is dim and cold. I stand by a window overlooking the surface rescue vessel's interior lights reflecting off metallic surfaces. My breath mingles with the hum of machinery—an endless drone that underscores every moment here above-water but not yet air.

My fingers tremble slightly as they trace the outline of my phone, resting in my pocket. It buzzes softly against my palm—a reminder that Mara is waiting for me to be ready. I clench it tightly then loosen again, feeling the cool metal beneath my fingertips. She’s given us this moment, and now it's time.

I exhale slowly through pursed lips, watching the condensation form a light fog on the glass before dissipating into the air of stale oxygen around me. My heart thrums with a steady rhythm—each beat echoing the pulse of responsibility that courses through every vein.

"Ready?" comes Mara’s voice from behind without turning to look over her shoulder just once more, as if checking for any lingering doubts in my eyes.

I take another deep breath and nod silently, my gaze still fixed on the glass. "Yes," I reply softly but confidently, turning away from the window towards where the others wait.

As we move down the corridor towards decompression chamber one last time today before debriefing officially begins, Mara’s pace sets an unspoken rhythm of determination—each footfall a drumbeat urging forward into new territory laid bare by surviving depths. Only now do I notice how quiet everything has become in this moment between life under water and living above.

The room where the air feels freshest despite oxygen levels still climbing back up to normal after hours trapped beneath pressure is empty except for Mara who stands at its center, looking towards me with a gaze as deep and clear as any underwater vista.

"Tell them everything," she says simply but firmly without needing further elaboration or prompting into specifics.

I swallow hard past the lump in my throat while pulling out my phone from pocket once more to begin recording—my voice steady even if hands hesitate briefly pressing start button amidst echoing silence filling space between us now that cameras record only memories and not live footage anymore.

"You’ve earned this," Mara adds, glancing towards Linnea who nods silently beside her in agreement.

I clear my throat then look down at the glass surface of device as screen flickers to life capturing first moments post-rescue: stark clarity reflected back into room through cold metal casing held tightly between fingers barely trembling now anymore.

"Okay," I breathe out deeply before lifting head and looking directly ahead, finding words that carry weight but don’t need them—truths unspoken beneath surface level will rise naturally speaking themselves clearer with each breath taken.

My eyes meet Linnea’s briefly across the space separating us both knowing what transpires here matters beyond immediate confines of vessel hull or debriefing room walls. Truth shared now lays foundation for future rebuilding on truth rather than shadows hiding behind mirrors reflecting back only illusions of safety and redemption away from depths no one can fully escape.

As I begin speaking into device, words flowing naturally as if guided by presence lingering even though not physically here—voices carried over phone lines connecting us all in this moment. Each sentence uttered feels like lifting a burden incrementally off shoulders now more than ever before—but Mara’s hand on shoulder halting motion reminds me of shared strength too.

"Take your time," her voice echoes softly but firmly around room bringing back focus to present task at hand—translating experience into narrative truth for those waiting beyond surface level.

My fingers tighten slightly once again as device is held up towards face, recording lights blinking reassuringly confirming capture began properly now finally ready to unveil full story hidden behind glass and mirrors long enough ago left only lingering echoes of secrets in darkness below where light fails.

"Everything I know," I begin hesitantly but with resolve nonetheless, "begins here."
